message_text: Paper Title: Distributed Event-Triggered Output-Feedback Time-Varying Formation Fault-Tolerant Control for Nonlinear Multi-Agent Systems Paper Abstract: This paper studies the event-triggered time-varying formation control problem for nonlinear multi-agent systems with actuator faults. Based on the neural network approximation technique, a neural observer is constructed to estimate the unmeasured states of systems. Then, a distributed adaptive event-triggered time-varying formation control manner is proposed utilizing the intermittent estimated states information from the agent and its neighbors. To overcome the problem that estimated states triggering leads to virtual control laws is non-differentiable, a distributed continuous control scheme under regular output-feedback is designed firstly, upon which a distributed event-triggered controller is constructed by replacing estimated states with intermittent estimated ones. It is shown that the designed event-triggered output-feedback time-varying formation fault-tolerant controller can compensate for actuator faults, and all signals in closed-loop systems are semi-globally uniformly ultimately bounded. Finally, simulation results of a practical example are given to verify the effectiveness of the proposed control manner. Note to Practitioners —Formation control has broad application prospects in modern military and civilian fields, such as combat aircraft flying formation, satellite formation, autonomous vehicle formation, etc. In formation control systems, when agents occur actuator faults, it may break the original formation and even cause collision between agents. As a result, the security of formation control systems is facing great challenges in practical engineering applications. On the other hand, communication bandwidth is limited in practical engineering systems, and how to make systems quickly form formation under the limited communication bandwidth has become a key topic. Inspired by the above discussions, a distributed state-triggered output-feedback time-varying formation fault-tolerant control scheme is designed in this paper, in which actuator faults are compensated by using adaptive technology. Meanwhile, to sufficiently save the usage of system communication resources, a dual-channel event-triggered mechanism is designed. "contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.) "survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work) task - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding) method - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction) data - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus) artifact - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9) tool - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope) concept - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory) other - Entities that don't fit above categories uses - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks) proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS: - ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work) - CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new) { "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey", "triples": [ { "name": "Wikipedia Article Title", "relation": "uses|proposes", "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other", "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...", "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)" } ] } FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool: CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do. 1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field. 2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation. 3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia. 4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm") - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes) - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/) - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters 5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py 6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes. When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter: WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"]) This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains. Begin now.

## Event-Triggered Control

Event-triggered control is a field of study in which researchers contribute to the analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems. A notable researcher in this field is Maurice Heemels, a Full Professor at Eindhoven University of Technology, who was named Fellow of the IEEE in 2016 for his contributions to analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems.

While the search results provided information about event-triggered systems and various event-driven concepts (like event-driven programming and event-driven architecture), they offer limited specific technical details about event-triggered control itself. 

Event-triggered control is an advanced control engineering concept that differs from traditional time-triggered systems in that control actions are initiated based on events (such as state deviations) rather than at fixed time intervals. If you need more detailed information about the technical aspects, mathematical foundations, or specific applications of event-triggered control, I'd recommend searching for academic papers or specialized control systems literature on this topic.

Web search results for query: "Multi-agent system"

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Talk:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about multi-agent systems:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.

## Capabilities and Benefits

Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Components

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment, and the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous, and no agent is designated as controlling.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Communication

When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language, within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to a common improvement, with example languages including Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's information about neural networks:

## Definition and Structure

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)In machine learning, a neural network is an artificial mathematical model used to approximate nonlinear functions.(no content)Neurons in an artificial neural network are usually arranged into layers, with information passing from the first layer (the input layer) through one or more intermediate layers (the hidden layers) to the final layer (the output layer).

## Applications

Neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

## Training

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference, or empirical risk, between the predicted output and the actual target values in a given dataset.(no content)Gradient-based methods such as backpropagation are usually used to estimate the parameters of the network.

## Historical Context

Today's deep neural networks are based on early work in statistics over 200 years ago.(no content)In 1958, psychologist Frank Rosenblatt described the perceptron, one of the first implemented artificial neural networks, funded by the United States Office of Naval Research.

Web search results for query: "Output-feedback control"

Links: [{"title":"Proportional–integral–derivative controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proportional–integral–derivative_controller"},{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"},{"title":"Negative feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_feedback"},{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic–Gaussian control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear–quadratic–Gaussian_control"},{"title":"System identification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_identification"}]

Based on the web search results, I found relevant information about output-feedback control:

Output feedback control aims to determine a control law that is optimal in the sense of minimizing the expected value of a quadratic cost criterion. This is in contrast to state feedback, where full state information is available.

Output measurements are assumed to be corrupted by Gaussian noise and the initial state is assumed to be a Gaussian random vector.

A prominent example of output feedback control is LQG (Linear-Quadratic-Gaussian) control, which applies to both linear time-invariant systems as well as linear time-varying systems, and constitutes a linear dynamic feedback control law that is easily computed and implemented.

In practical applications, a state observer (or state estimator) is a system that provides an estimate of the internal state of a given real system from measurements of the input and output of the real system, and it is typically computer-implemented and provides the basis of many practical applications. This is often used in conjunction with output feedback when the full system state cannot be directly measured.

The key challenge with output-feedback control is that in most practical cases, the physical state of the system cannot be determined by direct observation, and instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.

Based on the web search results, I found relevant information about output-feedback control:

Output feedback control aims to determine a control law that is optimal in the sense of minimizing the expected value of a quadratic cost criterion. This is in contrast to state feedback, where full state information is available.

Output measurements are assumed to be corrupted by Gaussian noise and the initial state is assumed to be a Gaussian random vector.

A prominent example of output feedback control is LQG (Linear-Quadratic-Gaussian) control, which applies to both linear time-invariant systems as well as linear time-varying systems, and constitutes a linear dynamic feedback control law that is easily computed and implemented.

In practical applications, a state observer (or state estimator) is a system that provides an estimate of the internal state of a given real system from measurements of the input and output of the real system, and it is typically computer-implemented and provides the basis of many practical applications. This is often used in conjunction with output feedback when the full system state cannot be directly measured.

The key challenge with output-feedback control is that in most practical cases, the physical state of the system cannot be determined by direct observation, and instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about adaptive control:

## Overview

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## How It Works

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.(no content)The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

## Types of Adaptive Control

Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters. There are also hybrid methods that combine both approaches.

## Applications

A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control. This body of work has focused on guaranteeing stability of a model reference adaptive control scheme using Lyapunov arguments.

Links: [{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Active disturbance rejection control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_disturbance_rejection_control"},{"title":"United Nations General Assembly observers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_observers"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"Observer pattern - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer_pattern?amp=&amp="},{"title":"State-space representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-space_representation"},{"title":"Talk:State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:State_observer"},{"title":"Separation principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle"},{"title":"Observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer"},{"title":"Observer status - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer_status"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about state observer control:

## State Observer Control

In control theory, a state observer, state estimator, or Luenberger observer is a system that provides an estimate of the internal state of a given real system, from measurements of the input and output of the real system.(no content)It is typically computer-implemented, and provides the basis of many practical applications.

### Purpose and Applications

Knowing the system state is necessary to solve many control theory problems; for example, stabilizing a system using state feedback.(no content)In most practical cases, the physical state of the system cannot be determined by direct observation. Instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.

### Key Concepts

If a system is observable, it is possible to fully reconstruct the system state from its output measurements using the state observer.(no content)In control theory, a separation principle states that under some assumptions the problem of designing an optimal feedback controller for a stochastic system can be solved by designing an optimal observer for the state of the system, which feeds into an optimal deterministic controller for the system. Thus the problem can be broken into two separate parts, which facilitates the design.

### Observer Design Approaches

Linear, delayed, sliding mode, high gain, Tau, homogeneity-based, extended and cubic observers are among several observer structures used for state estimation of linear and nonlinear systems.

Based on the search results, here's information about distributed control:

## Distributed Control System (DCS)

A distributed control system (DCS) is a computerized control system for a process or plant usually with many control loops, in which autonomous controllers are distributed throughout the system, but there is no central operator supervisory control.

### Key Benefits

The key attribute of a DCS is its reliability due to the distribution of the control processing around nodes in the system. This mitigates a single processor failure. If a processor fails, it will only affect one section of the plant process, as opposed to a failure of a central computer which would affect the whole process. Additionally, this distribution of computing power local to the field Input/Output (I/O) connection racks also ensures fast controller processing times by removing possible network and central processing delays.

### Architecture

Level 0 contains the field devices such as flow and temperature sensors, and final control elements, such as control valves. Level 1 contains the industrialised Input/Output (I/O) modules, and their associated distributed electronic processors. Level 2 contains the supervisory computers, which collect information from processor nodes on the system, and provide the operator control screens.

### Applications

Distributed control systems (DCS) are dedicated systems used in manufacturing processes that are continuous or batch-oriented.(no content)DCS tends to be used on large continuous process plants where high reliability and security is important, and the control room is not necessarily geographically remote.

Based on the search results, here's information about distributed control:

## Distributed Control System (DCS)

A distributed control system (DCS) is a computerized control system for a process or plant usually with many control loops, in which autonomous controllers are distributed throughout the system, but there is no central operator supervisory control.

### Key Benefits

The key attribute of a DCS is its reliability due to the distribution of the control processing around nodes in the system. This mitigates a single processor failure. If a processor fails, it will only affect one section of the plant process, as opposed to a failure of a central computer which would affect the whole process. Additionally, this distribution of computing power local to the field Input/Output (I/O) connection racks also ensures fast controller processing times by removing possible network and central processing delays.

### Architecture

Level 0 contains the field devices such as flow and temperature sensors, and final control elements, such as control valves. Level 1 contains the industrialised Input/Output (I/O) modules, and their associated distributed electronic processors. Level 2 contains the supervisory computers, which collect information from processor nodes on the system, and provide the operator control screens.

### Applications

Distributed control systems (DCS) are dedicated systems used in manufacturing processes that are continuous or batch-oriented.(no content)DCS tends to be used on large continuous process plants where high reliability and security is important, and the control room is not necessarily geographically remote.

Web search results for query: "Fault-tolerant control"

Links: [{"title":"Fault tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_tolerance"},{"title":"Control reconfiguration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_reconfiguration"},{"title":"Software fault tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_fault_tolerance"},{"title":"Jakob Stoustrup - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jakob_Stoustrup"},{"title":"Fault detection and isolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_detection_and_isolation"},{"title":"Safety-critical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safety-critical_system"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Fail-safe - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fail-safe"},{"title":"Quantum error correction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_error_correction"},{"title":"Fault Tolerant Ethernet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_Tolerant_Ethernet"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about fault-tolerant control:

## Overview

Fault tolerance is the ability of a system to maintain proper operation despite failures or faults in one or more of its components, and this capability is essential for high-availability, mission-critical, or even life-critical systems.

## Key Approaches

In control systems, there are two main strategies for achieving fault tolerance:

1. **Control Reconfiguration**: This is used when severe faults, such as actuator or sensor outages, cause a break-up of the control loop, which must be restructured to prevent failure at the system level, and the controller parameters must be adjusted to accommodate changed plant dynamics.

2. **Fault Accommodation**: Fault accommodation is another common approach to achieve fault tolerance, and in contrast to control reconfiguration, accommodation is limited to internal controller changes.

## Fault Diagnosis

Prior to control reconfiguration, it must be at least determined whether a fault has occurred (fault detection) and if so, which components are affected (fault isolation), and preferably a model of the faulty plant should be provided (fault identification), which are addressed by fault diagnosis methods.

## Applications

Fault-tolerant systems avoid service failure when faults are introduced to the system, with examples including control systems for ordinary nuclear reactors. Other practical applications include aircraft autopilot systems and various safety-critical control systems.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Nonlinear control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Describing function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Describing_function"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Linear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"}]

Based on the web search results, here's a comprehensive overview of nonlinear control systems:

## Definition and Overview

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)It applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

## Key Characteristics

Nonlinear control systems have several distinguishing properties:

- Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle.
- These systems are often governed by nonlinear differential equations.
- They may exhibit properties such as limit cycle, bifurcation, chaos.

## Analysis and Design Techniques

The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems. These include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.(no content)If only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used.

## Practical Applications

An example of a nonlinear control system is a thermostat-controlled heating system. A building heating system such as a furnace has a nonlinear response to changes in temperature; it is either "on" or "off", it does not have the fine control in response to temperature differences that a proportional (linear) device would have.

Other modern applications include robotics and the aerospace industry, which typically have strong nonlinear dynamics.
